summary: This is a civil complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein and several corporate entities (The 1953 Trust, Plan D, LLC, Great St. Jim, LLC, Nautilus, Inc., Hyperion Air, LLC, Poplar, Inc.). The complaint alleges that Epstein and his associates used a complex network of Virgin Islands-based companies to facilitate, conceal, and carry out a sex trafficking and abuse enterprise involving young women and underage girls on his private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James, from at least 2001 through 2018. The GVI seeks damages for violations of Virgin Islands laws. This document is a portion of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. It details the Epstein Enterprise's use of private islands (Little St. James and Great St. James) to traffic, abuse, and isolate victims, its efforts to conceal activities from law enforcement, and its violations of Virgin Islands laws including human trafficking, forced labor, and environmental statutes. The complaint seeks civil penalties and forfeiture of assets. This document is a portion of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), alleging that Epstein and other unnamed defendants operated an illicit enterprise engaged in human trafficking, sexual servitude, child abuse, rape, and related crimes in the Virgin Islands. This document is a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and associated entities, alleging numerous violations of the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO). It details counts including human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, prostitution, sex offender registry violations, and fraudulent conveyance of assets into 'The 1953 Trust' prior to Epstein's death.

events.title: Acquisition of Little St. James
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein acquired the private island of Little St. James in the Virgin Islands, which the complaint alleges became a primary location for his sex trafficking and abuse enterprise.

events.title: Epstein Registers as Sex Offender in Virgin Islands
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein registered as a Tier 1 sex offender in the Virgin Islands following his Florida conviction for procuring a minor for prostitution.

events.title: Purchase of Great St. James
events.description: Epstein, through Great St. Jim, LLC, purchased the neighboring island of Great St. James, which the complaint alleges was to further shield his criminal activities on Little St. James.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead while in custody in New York on charges of sex crimes.

events.title: Estate Probate Filed
events.description: Executors Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn filed a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary for Epstein's estate in the Virgin Islands Superior Court.

events.title: Pattern of Trafficking and Abuse in Virgin Islands
events.description: The complaint alleges that between 2001 and 2019, the Epstein Enterprise transported underage girls and young women to the Virgin Islands to be sexually abused and exploited on Little St. James.

events.title: Acquisition of Great St. James
events.description: The Epstein Enterprise, using a straw purchaser to hide Epstein's identity, acquired Great St. James island for over $20 million to prevent others from viewing activities on Little St. James and to create barriers preventing escape.

events.title: Sex Offender Registration Verification Refusal
events.description: Epstein refused to permit Virgin Islands Department of Justice Investigators and U.S. Marshals to enter Little St. James beyond its dock for a sex offender address verification, insisting on meeting at his office on St. Thomas instead.

events.title: Undisclosed Travel to Europe
events.description: Epstein notified the Virgin Islands he would travel to France for 10 days but did not disclose additional travel to Vienna and Monaco, misleading authorities about his movements.

events.title: Estate Files Motion for Claims Program
events.description: Epstein's Estate filed an Expedited Motion for Establishment of a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program in the Virgin Islands Superior Court, proposing a confidential program to resolve sexual abuse claims.

events.title: Asset Transfer to The 1953 Trust
events.description: Epstein, days before his death, transferred significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust' in an alleged effort to defeat creditor claims and avoid court oversight of his estate.

events.title: Undisclosed Foreign Travel
events.description: Epstein traveled to Vienna and Monaco on at least two occasions without disclosing the travel to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry as required by law.

keyFacts: The Government of the Virgin Islands alleges Jeffrey Epstein operated a criminal 'Epstein Enterprise' that used a network of Virgin Islands corporate entities to traffic, sexually abuse, and hold captive young women and underage girls on his private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James.

Epstein's estate, valued at over $577 million in Virgin Islands assets alone, is being sued for damages, along with specific corporate entities (Nautilus, Inc., Great St. Jim, LLC, Poplar, Inc., Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) that held his properties and aircraft, which the complaint alleges were instrumentalities of his crimes.

The complaint details specific abusive incidents, including a 15-year-old victim who attempted to escape Little St. James by swimming away and was retrieved by a search party organized by Epstein, who then confiscated her passport.

Epstein's pilot, Larry Visoski, is identified as the manager/member of corporate entities (Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) that owned the aircraft used to transport victims to and within the Virgin Islands.

Epstein created 'The 1953 Trust' and revised his will just two days before his death, transferring all his property to the trust, which the Virgin Islands government also names as a defendant responsible for damages.
Epstein's private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James, were used to traffic, abuse, and isolate young women and children, who were unable to leave without his permission.
The Epstein Enterprise purchased Great St. James in 2016 for over $20 million using a straw purchaser, primarily to prevent observation of activities on Little St. James and to hinder escapes.

Epstein and his enterprise repeatedly violated Virgin Islands construction and environmental laws, incurring fines that were ineffective due to his wealth, and attempted to prevent government inspections.

The enterprise used a complex network of corporate entities (e.g., Plan D, LLC, Great St. Jim, LLC, Nautilus, Inc.) to conceal assets, fund criminal activities, and shield participants from liability.

Epstein, as a registered sex offender, actively misled Virgin Islands authorities about his travel and refused full compliance with in-person verification checks, demonstrating efforts to conceal his conduct.

The complaint formally alleges that Jeffrey Epstein and other unnamed defendants operated a criminal enterprise (the 'Epstein Enterprise') in violation of the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO).

The enterprise is accused of luring young women and underage girls to the Virgin Islands under false pretenses (like modeling opportunities) to engage in sexual acts with Epstein and others, often in exchange for money, gifts, or scholarships.
The listed criminal counts include human trafficking for sexual servitude, child abuse and neglect, aggravated rape, second-degree rape, unlawful sexual contact, and prostitution.
The complaint alleges that Epstein's property on Little St. James was used as a location for prostitution and sexual activity.

The document is a legal filing (part of a complaint) and does not name specific co-conspirators, victims, or witnesses; it refers to them collectively as 'Defendants,' 'others,' 'young women,' and 'underage girls.'
The complaint alleges the 'Epstein Enterprise' directed, transported, and received women and children at Little St. James for purposes of prostitution and sexual activity, knowing some were minors.
Epstein allegedly violated the Virgin Islands sex offender registry laws by failing to report travel to Vienna and Monaco.
Days before his death, Epstein transferred significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust', which the GVI alleges was a fraudulent conveyance to hinder creditors and the probate court.
The Government seeks severe penalties including forfeiture of Epstein's Virgin Islands properties (Little St. James and Greater St. James), dissolution of the enterprise, and punitive damages.
The document frames the activities as a pattern of criminal enterprise (CICO) involving human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude, not isolated incidents.
